question.title: If Tim Scott is the Republican nominee, will 538 project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Tim Scott is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This means Tim Scott is the Republican nominee.

Then, is it true that Joe Biden will have a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024?

Resolution criteria for the condition: Resolves Yes if Tim Scott is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Resolves No otherwise.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves Yes if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for July 19, 2024. Resolves No if Donald Trump has a higher probability. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, resolves 50-50. The resolution source is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast.

not_P.title: If Tim Scott is the Republican nominee, will 538 project Biden as the underdog on July 19, 2024?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: Tim Scott is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This means Tim Scott is the Republican nominee.

Then, is it true that Joe Biden will not have a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024?

Resolution criteria for the condition: Resolves Yes if Tim Scott is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Resolves No otherwise.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves Yes if Joe Biden does not have a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for July 19, 2024. Resolves No if Biden has a higher probability. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, resolves 50-50. The resolution source is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast.

para_P.title: Should Tim Scott become the Republican candidate, will FiveThirtyEight indicate Biden as the frontrunner on July 19, 2024?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following holds true: Tim Scott is chosen by the Republican National Convention as the candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This confirms that Tim Scott is the Republican candidate.

Then, is it accurate to say that Joe Biden will have a greater chance of winning the US presidential election compared to Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election prediction for July 19, 2024?

Criteria for resolving the condition: Resolves Yes if Tim Scott is chosen by the Republican National Convention as the candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Resolves No otherwise.

Criteria for resolving the outcome: Resolves Yes if Joe Biden has a greater chance of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election prediction for July 19, 2024. Resolves No if Donald Trump has a greater chance. If Biden and Trump have the same odds, resolves 50-50. The source for resolution is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast.

question.title: Will Tim Scott be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and will FiveThirtyEight project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Tim Scott is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined solely by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention. (b) Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If both conditions are not met, this question will resolve as **No**. 

For the first condition, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by the selection at the Republican National Convention.

For the second condition, the resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19, 2024. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

not_P.title: Will Tim Scott not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election or will FiveThirtyEight not project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024?
not_P.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if at least one of the following conditions is met: (a) Tim Scott is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined solely by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention. (b) Joe Biden does not have a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If both conditions are met, this question will resolve as **No**. 

For the first condition, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by the selection at the Republican National Convention.

For the second condition, the resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19, 2024. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

para_P.title: Is Tim Scott going to be the Republican candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and will FiveThirtyEight indicate Biden as the frontrunner on July 19, 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will conclude as **Yes** if both of the following criteria are fulfilled: (a) Tim Scott is chosen by the Republican National Convention as the candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined exclusively by the choice made by the delegates of the Republican National Convention. (b) Joe Biden is projected to have a greater chance of winning the US presidential election compared to Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for July 19, 2024. If either of these criteria is not satisfied, this inquiry will conclude as **No**. 

Regarding the first criterion, it does not matter who is nominated by the Republican Party on the day of the 2024 US election; the determination is solely based on the selection made at the Republican National Convention.

For the second criterion, the source for resolution will be FiveThirtyEight's forecast for the 2024 presidential election, specifically the values shown by the blue and red trend lines for July 19, 2024. Any changes in the method used by FiveThirtyEight to compute its figures will not affect the resolution. If there are no data points available for July 19 by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve based on the closest preceding figures to July 19.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

not_P.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be less than or equal to 3 or greater than 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
not_P.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

para_P.title: On July 15, 2024, will Donald Trump's advantage over Joe Biden be more than 3 but not exceed 4 according to the national polling average from 538?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will conclude based on the difference in favor of Donald Trump over Joe Biden as indicated by 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) on the chart dated July 15, 2024, when reviewed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

In this context, a positive figure indicates a lead for Trump, whereas a negative figure signifies Biden's lead. For instance, on July 5, 2024, the reported value shows Trump leading Biden by 2.4 points, which translates to a positive value of 2.4 for the purpose of this inquiry.

question.title: Conditional on Trump's lead over Biden being greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, will Chris Christie be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average is greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 points, as reported by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. This means a positive value between 3 and 4 points, inclusive, indicating a Trump lead.

Given this condition, will Chris Christie be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? This resolution is based solely on the selection by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who is the nominee on the day of the 2024 US election.

not_P.title: Conditional on Trump's lead over Biden being less than or equal to 3 or greater than 4 on July 15, 2024, will Chris Christie not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average is less than or equal to 3 points or greater than 4 points, as reported by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. This means a non-positive value or a value greater than 4 points, indicating no Trump lead.

Given this condition, will Chris Christie not be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? This resolution is based solely on the selection by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who is the nominee on the day of the 2024 US election.

para_P.title: Assuming Trump's advantage over Biden is more than 3 but not exceeding 4 on July 15, 2024, will Chris Christie be the Republican candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
para_P.body:
Let us consider the following scenario: On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump holds a lead over Joe Biden in the 538 national polling average that is greater than 3 and at most 4 points, as noted by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. This indicates a positive margin between 3 and 4 points, inclusive, signifying a Trump lead.

Under this premise, will Chris Christie be chosen by the Republican National Convention as the candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election? This determination relies solely on the decision made by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, irrespective of who is declared the nominee on the day of the 2024 US election.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, and (b) Chris Christie be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

(b) This question will resolve as **Yes** if Chris Christie is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future. For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur: (a) Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, nor (b) Chris Christie be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
not_P.body:
(a) This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

(b) This question will resolve as **No** if Chris Christie is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **Yes**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future. For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

para_P.title: Is it possible that both of the following events will take place: (a) Trump's margin over Biden will exceed 3 but not surpass 4 on July 15, 2024, based on 538's national polling average, and (b) Chris Christie will be the Republican candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
para_P.body:
(a) This inquiry will conclude as Donald Trump's advantage over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as indicated on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when viewed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. For this question, a positive figure indicates a lead for Trump, while a negative figure signifies that Biden is ahead. For instance, as of July 5, 2024, the reported value for that date shows Trump 2.4 points in front of Biden, which would be interpreted as a positive value of 2.4 for the purposes of this question.

(b) This question will resolve as **Yes** if Chris Christie is chosen by the Republican National Convention as the candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election. question.title: Will an athlete win more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with **Yes** if any athlete achieves a minimum of two medals in tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

question.title: Given an athlete wins more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics, will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question explores the scenario where at least one athlete wins two or more medals in tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics. Under this condition:

- The question resolves as **No** if women's teams from eight different National Olympic Committees (NOCs) win gold in these eight team sports at the 2024 Paris Olympics:
  - Association football
  - 3×3 basketball
  - 5×5 basketball
  - Field hockey
  - Handball
  - Rugby sevens
  - Volleyball
  - Water polo.

- Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as **Yes**.

The question can resolve as soon as it becomes clear one of these conditions will happen (e.g., neither team playing the final of the last event has won any of the others).

not_P.title: Given an athlete does not win more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics, will the same nation not win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
not_P.body:

- The question resolves as **Yes** if women's teams from eight different National Olympic Committees (NOCs) win gold in these eight team sports at the 2024 Paris Olympics:
  - Association football
  - 3×3 basketball
  - 5×5 basketball
  - Field hockey
  - Handball
  - Rugby sevens
  - Volleyball
  - Water polo.

- Otherwise, the same NOC must not have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as **No**.

The question can resolve as soon as it becomes clear one of these conditions will happen (e.g., neither team playing the final of the last event has won any of the others).

- The answer is **No** if women's teams from eight distinct National Olympic Committees (NOCs) claim gold in the following eight team sports at the 2024 Paris Olympics:
  - Association football
  - 3×3 basketball
  - 5×5 basketball
  - Field hockey
  - Handball
  - Rugby sevens
  - Volleyball
  - Water polo.

- Conversely, if this does not occur, the same NOC must have secured at least two of these competitions, resulting in a **Yes** answer.

The question can be resolved as soon as it is evident that one of these conditions will take place (for instance, if neither team competing in the final of the last event has won any of the previous ones).

question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met at the 2024 Paris Olympics: 

(a) An athlete wins at least two medals for tennis.

(b) The same National Olympic Committee (NOC) wins gold in at least two of the following women's team sports: association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. question.title: Conditional on Francis Suarez being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body:
This question explores the relationship between the Republican and Democratic nomination processes for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

Condition: Francis Suarez must be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

Outcome: The question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

not_P.title: Conditional on Francis Suarez being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, will Democrats not have a brokered convention in 2024?
not_P.body:
This question explores the relationship between the Republican and Democratic nomination processes for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

Condition: Francis Suarez must be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

Outcome: The question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party does not require more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If more than one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

para_P.title: Assuming Francis Suarez is the chosen Republican candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election, will the Democratic Party encounter a brokered convention in 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry examines the interplay between the nomination procedures of the Republican and Democratic parties for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

Condition: Francis Suarez must be chosen as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election by the Republican National Convention, a decision made by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

Outcome: The question is answered with **Yes** if the Democratic Party needs to conduct multiple rounds of voting in its roll call ballot to officially nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. Conversely, if only a single ballot is necessary, the answer will be **No**.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Francis Suarez is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election (b) Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: (a) Francis Suarez will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election if he is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee. This is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not who is on the ballot on the day of the election. (b) The Democrats will have a brokered convention in 2024 if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur: (a) Francis Suarez is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election (b) Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
not_P.body: (a) Francis Suarez will not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election if he is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee. This is determined by who is not selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not who is on the ballot on the day of the election. (b) The Democrats will not have a brokered convention in 2024 if the Democratic Party does not require more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election.

para_P.title: Is it possible that both of these events happen: (a) Francis Suarez becomes the Republican candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election (b) the Democrats experience a brokered convention in 2024?
para_P.body: (a) Francis Suarez will be the Republican candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election if he is chosen by the Republican National Convention as their nominee. This choice is made by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, rather than who appears on the ballot during the election day. (b) The Democrats will undergo a brokered convention in 2024 if the Democratic Party needs more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to officially nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

not_P.title: Will Biden not be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
not_P.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) do not invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and do not cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker does not ask Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office.

para_P.title: Will Biden be deemed incapacitated under Section 4 of the 25th Amendment prior to August?
para_P.body:
This question resolves to YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant authority) activate Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to officially state that "the President is unable to fulfill the powers and responsibilities of his office" and appoint the Vice President as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The length of the incapacity is irrelevant to this inquiry.

Biden leaving the Presidency due to death, resignation, etc., is not included. Biden's invocation of Section 3 of the 25th Amendment is also excluded.

Context: A GOP lawmaker requests Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment to remove Biden from his position.

question.title: If Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August, will he announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Before August 2024, the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that Biden is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office, causing the Vice President to serve as Acting President. Note that Biden exiting the office by death, resignation, etc., or invoking Section 3 of the 25th Amendment does not count.

Then, will Joe Biden or his campaign make a definitive, public, official announcement before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, stating that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle? To resolve as Yes, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility of accepting the nomination.

not_P.title: If Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August, will he announce before July 15, 2024, that he will accept the Democratic Party's nomination?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: Before August 2024, the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that Biden is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office, causing the Vice President to serve as Acting President. Note that Biden exiting the office by death, resignation, etc., or invoking Section 3 of the 25th Amendment does not count.

Then, will Joe Biden or his campaign make a definitive, public, official announcement before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, stating that he will seek and will accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle? To resolve as Yes, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility of rejecting the nomination.

para_P.title: Should Biden be deemed incapacitated according to Section 4 of the 25th Amendment prior to August, will he officially declare by July 15, 2024, that he will decline the Democratic Party's nomination?
para_P.body:
Assume the following scenario: Prior to August 2024, the Vice President along with a majority of the Cabinet (or another appropriate authority) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to officially state that Biden is unable to fulfill the responsibilities of his office, resulting in the Vice President taking on the role of Acting President. It is important to note that Biden leaving office due to death, resignation, or the invocation of Section 3 of the 25th Amendment is not applicable.

In this case, will Joe Biden or his campaign make a clear, public, and official statement before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, indicating that he will not pursue and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 election? For the answer to be Yes, the announcement must be clear and definitive, allowing no possibility of him accepting the nomination.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 and (b) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
(a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024: Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

(b) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President: This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur: (a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 nor (b) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
not_P.body:
(a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024: Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

(b) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President: This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

para_P.title: Is it possible for both of the following to happen: (a) Biden being declared unable to perform his duties under the 25th Amendment Section 4 prior to August 2024 and (b) Joe Biden publicly stating before July 15, 2024 that he will decline the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
para_P.body:
(a) Biden being declared unable to perform his duties under the 25th Amendment Section 4 prior to August 2024: This resolves to YES if the Vice President along with a majority of the Cabinet (or another relevant entity) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to officially declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and causes the Vice President to act as President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The length of the incapacity is irrelevant for this question. Instances of Biden leaving the Presidency due to death, resignation, etc., are excluded. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment is also not applicable.

(b) Joe Biden publicly stating before July 15, 2024 that he will decline the Democratic Party's nomination for President: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a clear, public, official announcement indicating that Joe Biden will not pursue and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. For a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be clear and definitive: it should eliminate any possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not issued prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

question.title: Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by fewer than 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of fewer than 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES.

This market will resolve to YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 Democratic House Members or Senators before the market closes at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple letters with a total of 20 lawmakers' signatures would also suffice to resolve this market to YES. 

If these conditions are not fulfilled by market close, this market will resolve to NO.

A letter drafted by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and acquired by POLITICO signals the first public indication from Democrats since the recent assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump that many of their members are quite concerned about Biden’s candidacy. “This is a terrible decision by the DNC. Someone believes it’s a smart tactic to stifle debate and force unity, but that approach is ineffective,” Huffman stated in an interview. He did not confirm whether the letter exists. This market will resolve YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination strategy is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who are part of the Democratic Party before the market closes on Sunday, July 21st. Multiple letters totaling 20 signatures from lawmakers will also suffice for this market to resolve to YES. If these conditions are not satisfied by market closure, this market will resolve to NO.

(b) This question will be answered Yes if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to officially nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only a single ballot is needed, then the answer will be No.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

not_P.title: Will Democrats not have a brokered convention in 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires only one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If more than one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

para_P.title: Is a brokered convention expected for the Democrats in 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will result in **Yes** if the Democratic Party needs multiple rounds of voting during its roll call ballot to officially select its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. Conversely, if only a single ballot is needed, the outcome will be **No**.

question.title: Conditional on Democrats having a brokered convention in 2024, will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
This question explores the scenario where the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. In this context, we want to know if at least 20 House or Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the Democratic National Committee's plan to virtually nominate President Joe Biden early.

Resolution criteria for the condition: The Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

not_P.title: Conditional on Democrats having a brokered convention in 2024, will fewer than 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
not_P.body:
This question explores the scenario where the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. In this context, we want to know if fewer than 20 House or Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the Democratic National Committee's plan to virtually nominate President Joe Biden early.

Resolution criteria for the condition: The Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves YES if fewer than 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party sign a public letter opposing the early nomination plan before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. If these criteria are met by market close, this market resolves YES.

para_P.title: Assuming the Democrats hold a brokered convention in 2024, will a minimum of 20 House or Senate Democrats endorse a public letter against the proposal to nominate Biden virtually at an early stage?
para_P.body:
This inquiry considers the situation where the Democratic Party needs to conduct more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to officially nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. In this scenario, we seek to determine if at least 20 Democrats from the House or Senate will endorse a public letter opposing the Democratic National Committee's initiative to virtually nominate President Joe Biden ahead of schedule.

Criteria for the condition: The Democratic Party needs to have more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to officially nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election.

Criteria for the outcome: Resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination initiative is endorsed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who align with the Democratic Party before the market closes at the end of Sunday, July 21st. A collection of such letters totaling 20 lawmakers' endorsements would also suffice to resolve this market to YES. If these conditions are not fulfilled by market close, this market resolves NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024 (b) At least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
(a) The Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this condition is not met.

(b) A public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also meet this condition. If these criteria are not met by market close, this condition is not met.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur: (a) Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024 (b) At least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
not_P.body:
(a) The Democratic Party does not require more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this condition is met.

(b) A public letter opposing the early nomination plan is not signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. No such letters or letters with a combined total of fewer than 20 lawmaker's signatures would also meet this condition. If these criteria are met by market close, this condition is met.

para_P.title: Are both of the following events going to happen: (a) The Democrats will have a contested convention in 2024 (b) A minimum of 20 Democratic House or Senate members will endorse a public letter against the proposal to nominate Biden early?
para_P.body:
(a) The Democratic Party must have more than one voting round in its roll call ballot to officially select its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only a single ballot is needed, then this requirement is not fulfilled.

(b) A public letter opposing the early nomination strategy is endorsed by at least 20 House Representatives or Senators affiliated with the Democratic Party before the market closes on Sunday, July 21st. Multiple letters that together have 20 lawmakers' signatures would also satisfy this requirement. If these conditions are not fulfilled by the market close, this requirement is not fulfilled.

question.title: Given the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee is a Woman, will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: The Democratic delegates select a female presidential nominee for the 2024 election.

Then, consider the following: Will the same National Olympic Committee (NOC) win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics? This question resolves as No if women's teams representing eight different NOCs win gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as Yes.

not_P.title: Given the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee is a Woman, will the same nation not win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?

Now, ponder this: Will the same National Olympic Committee (NOC) achieve victories in more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics? This inquiry will result in a No if women's teams from eight distinct NOCs clinch gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. Conversely, if at least two of these events are won by the same NOC, the question will resolve as Yes.

question.body:
(a) The question about the Democratic Presidential Nominee will resolve “yes” if/when the Democratic delegates select a female presidential nominee for the 2024 election. It will resolve “no” if/when the Democratic delegates select a male presidential nominee for the 2024 election.

(b) The question about the 2024 Olympics will resolve as No if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as Yes.

(b) The question about the 2024 Olympics will resolve as No if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as Yes.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of the following will happen: (a) A Woman will be the Democratic Presidential Nominee for 2024 (b) The same country will achieve victory in more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
para_P.body:
(a) The inquiry regarding the Democratic Presidential Nominee will be answered with “yes” if the Democratic delegates choose a female candidate for the presidential race in 2024. It will be answered with “no” if a male candidate is selected by the Democratic delegates for the 2024 election.

(b) The query concerning the 2024 Olympics will be answered as No if women’s teams from eight distinct National Olympic Committees (NOC) secure gold medals in the eight team sports: association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. Conversely, the answer will be Yes if at least two of these events are won by the same NOC.

question.title: Given a Trump family member is the Republican nominee in 2024, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents facing Biden?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: A member of the Trump family becomes the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. This includes Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump.

Then, will Donald Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents when facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat? There are two Manifold polls that close on July 6. One poll asks respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat. This question resolves YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in the poll with Joe Biden exceeds that in the poll with a generic Democrat by 3% or more when both polls close. The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)). The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 minus the formula for poll 2 is greater than or equal to 0.03. Otherwise, it is NO.

not_P.title: Given a Trump family member is the Republican nominee in 2024, will Trump gain less than 3% among Manifold respondents facing Biden?

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)). The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 minus the formula for poll 2 is less than 0.03. Otherwise, it is NO.

In that case, will Donald Trump secure at least a 3% advantage among Manifold respondents when competing against Joe Biden rather than a generic Democrat? There are two Manifold polls concluding on July 6. One poll solicits votes with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, while the other asks for votes with a generic Democrat. This inquiry will resolve as YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in the poll with Joe Biden surpasses that in the poll with a generic Democrat by 3% or more at the time both polls close. The calculation for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)). The outcome is YES if the result from poll 1 minus the result from poll 2 is greater than or equal to 0.03. Otherwise, the answer is NO.

The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03. Otherwise, it is NO. The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of the following will take place: (a) a Trump family member becomes the Republican candidate for the US Presidency in 2024 and (b) when competing against Joe Biden rather than a generic Democrat, will Trump achieve at least a 3% increase in support among Manifold participants?

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

not_P.title: Will Biden not be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
not_P.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) do not invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and do not cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker does not ask Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office.

para_P.title: Will Biden be deemed incapacitated according to Section 4 of the 25th Amendment prior to August?
para_P.body:
This resolves to YES if the Vice President along with a majority of the Cabinet (or another appropriate body) activates Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to officially state that "the President is unable to fulfill the powers and responsibilities of his office" and allows the Vice President to act as President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The length of the incapacity is irrelevant for this inquiry.

Biden leaving the Presidential office due to death, resignation, etc., is not included. Biden's self-invocation of section 3 of the 25th Amendment is also not included.

Context: A GOP legislator urges Merrick Garland to activate the 25th Amendment to remove Biden from his position.

question.title: Given Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August, will 538 project him as the favorite on July 19, 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. This means the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) have invoked Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

Then, is it true that Joe Biden will have a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024? This will resolve to “Yes” if Biden is projected as more likely to win than Trump according to FiveThirtyEight's forecast. It will resolve to “No” if Trump is projected as more likely to win. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this will resolve 50-50. The resolution source is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19, 2024.

not_P.title: Given Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August, will 538 not project him as the favorite on July 19, 2024?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. This means the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) have invoked Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

Then, is it true that Joe Biden will not have a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024? This will resolve to “Yes” if Biden is projected as less likely to win than Trump according to FiveThirtyEight's forecast. It will resolve to “No” if Biden is projected as more likely to win than Trump. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this will resolve 50-50. The resolution source is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19, 2024.

para_P.title: If Biden is deemed incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 prior to August, will 538 indicate him as the frontrunner on July 19, 2024?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following holds true: Biden is deemed incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. This means the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant authority) have invoked Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to officially declare that "the President is unable to fulfill the powers and responsibilities of his office" and allow the Vice President to act as President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

Then, is it accurate to say that Joe Biden will have a greater chance of winning the US presidential election compared to Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election prediction for July 19, 2024? This will conclude with “Yes” if Biden is forecasted as more likely to win than Trump according to FiveThirtyEight's projection. It will conclude with “No” if Trump is forecasted as more likely to win. If Biden and Trump have equal chances, this will resolve 50-50. The resolution source is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, particularly the figures indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19, 2024.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, and (b) 538 project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024?
question.body:
(a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024: Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.
(b) 538 project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024: This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50. The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market. This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19. Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

not_P.title: Will at least one of the following not occur: (a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, or (b) 538 project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024?
not_P.body:
(a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024: Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.
(b) 538 project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024: This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50. The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market. This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19. Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

para_P.title: Is it possible for both of the following to happen: (a) Biden to be officially recognized as incapacitated under Section 4 of the 25th Amendment prior to August 2024, and (b) 538 to indicate Biden as the frontrunner on July 19, 2024?
para_P.body:
(a) For Biden to be officially recognized as incapacitated under Section 4 of the 25th Amendment before August 2024: This will resolve to YES if the Vice President along with a majority of the Cabinet (or another appropriate body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally state that "the President is unable to perform the powers and duties of his office" and appoint the Vice President as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The length of the incapacity is not relevant to this question. Events such as Biden leaving the presidency due to death, resignation, etc., are not included. Biden's invocation of Section 3 of the 25th Amendment is also excluded.
(b) For 538 to indicate Biden as the frontrunner on July 19, 2024: This market will be marked as “Yes” if Joe Biden is projected to have a greater chance of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for July 19, 2024. It will be marked “No” if Donald Trump is projected to have a better chance of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden on that date. If both candidates are given equal probabilities, this market will resolve to 50-50. The source for resolution will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the blue and red trend lines for the resolution date. Any changes in how FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will not affect the outcome of this market. The market will resolve based on the data for July 19 as soon as data for July 20 becomes available. It may not resolve until data for July 20 is ready. If there are no data points for July 19 by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, then the resolution will be based on the closest previous figures to July 19. The resolution refers to the winning odds of each candidate expressed as a number out of 100 rounded to one decimal place (e.g., "Trump 57 out of 100"). The number of simulations won by each candidate out of 1,000 will not be taken into account.

question.title: Will Albania qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Albania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. The question will resolve as **No** for all other outcomes regarding Albania.

not_P.title: Will Albania not qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Albania does not participate in a Semi-final or is not officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. The question will resolve as **No** for all other outcomes regarding Albania.

para_P.title: Is Albania going to make it to the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude with a **Yes** if Albania competes in a Semi-final and is officially recognized by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having secured a spot in the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. It will be marked as **No** for all other scenarios concerning Albania.

question.title: Given Albania qualifies for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, will Iceland qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: Suppose the following is true: Albania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. Then, will Iceland participate in a Semi-final and be officially announced by the EBU as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final?

not_P.title: Given Albania qualifies for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, will Iceland not qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
not_P.body: Suppose the following is true: Albania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. Then, will Iceland participate in a Semi-final and not be officially announced by the EBU as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final?

para_P.title: If Albania makes it to the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, will Iceland also make it to the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
para_P.body: Assuming the following holds true: Albania takes part in a Semi-final and the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) confirms that Albania has qualified for the Grand Final of Eurovision 2024. In that case, will Iceland compete in a Semi-final and be confirmed by the EBU as having qualified for the Grand Final of Eurovision 2024?

question.title: Will both Albania and Iceland qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following occur: (a) Albania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, and (b) Iceland participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. The question will resolve as **No** if either or both countries do not qualify for the Grand Final.

not_P.title: Will neither Albania nor Iceland qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if neither of the following occur: (a) Albania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, nor (b) Iceland participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. The question will resolve as **No** if either Albania or Iceland qualifies for the Grand Final.

para_P.title: Are both Albania and Iceland going to make it to the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be resolved as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Albania competes in a Semi-final and is formally declared by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having secured a spot in the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, and (b) Iceland competes in a Semi-final and is formally declared by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having secured a spot in the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. The inquiry will be resolved as **No** if either or both nations fail to qualify for the Grand Final.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

This market will resolve to “No” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024.
